name: dusty
text: I looked it up on Google and apparently its a mentally handicapped fellow who has been outfitted with a helmet (presumably for his protection). Unfortunately he has gotten a hold of some little swords and put one of his eyes out before lodging the swords in the back of his helmet. Or in this case a whole team of them.

text:
Is that a typo? Is Cornelius supposed to be asking for the "document" instead of the "instrument"?

I don't want to believe it's a mistake, so I hope someone can explain to me that I'm being an idiot and "instrument" makes sense.

name: closefriend
text: Ray asked for a laser pointer because he is a cat. But he forgot that in order for a cat to properly enjoy a laser pointer, he needs someone else to operate it.

name: soticoto
text:
Bollocks, mate.
Ray has hands that can hold things. Ray gets things done.

Besides... I'd also want a laser pointer if I became retarded for a few days and needed some totally mindless entertainment. It isn't just for cats y'know.

i wish doctors in the real world still wore those things on their noggins.

it says to the patient, 'I am so confident in my doctor abilities that I can wear this thing on my head and not even be bothered. now let's get down to business.'

name: nabeel84
text: You think he's asking for the 500 mile long laser pointer? I'm not sure the others are ready for the eBay platinum, but 7 million should cover it. And I can't see how that wouldn't be fun while stoned.

name: sstralka
text: On further reflection I'm wondering if this strip isn't a variation on that old joke where the doctor says, "I have bad news and good news.  The bad news is you have an inoperable brain tumor.  The good news is I just inherited seven million dollars."

text: Achewood obviously doesn't play well in New York. Either that, or someone has decided to show their opposition to a comic about mental retardation in the worst way possible.

name: goatmasterflash
text: Ray is truly blessed to have been rendered retarded in his time of greatest risk of attack from his old nemesis diabetes. While slightly different from the well-feared Diabetes Mellitus (aka "The Sugar"), it is not uncommon to develop Diabetes Insipidus following a traumatic head injury.

name: dasilodavi
text: There is a ridiculous amount of over-laming on this particular strip.  Why must we hate on posts?
